utterances: Carrie Johnson has a question for you, Mr. Attorney General.
Yeah.

I just wonder, General Gonzales, whether you think that perhaps Mueller may have left this call to Congress, and the DOJ leadership, instead, decided to weigh in and shut the door before it got to lawmakers on Capitol Hill?

Again, knowing Bob Mueller, I think he would've been quite comfortable in sort of the chain of command and knowing that, at the end of the day, it's the attorney general within the executive branch who makes the final call with respect to prosecutions.
I don't think this - because the standards are different.
Congress will not be looking with respect to prosecution of a crime.
What Congress is going to be looking at is whether or not this is an impeachable offense.
And so I think for Bob Mueller, my own sense is that what he's thinking about is whether or not - has a crime been committed here that can be prosecuted?
And so I don't think this is a situation where he was thinking, I'm going to leave this for Congress to decide.
Very briefly, General Gonzales - Dean Gonzales, as well, because you're dean of the law school at Belmont University.
The president says he's been exonerated.
Has he been, in your view?
I think with respect to the collusion and cooperation, he certainly has.
And, you know, whether you call it exonerate or what, I mean, I think the main objective here is that he's not to be prosecuted for obstruction of justice.
So, you know, I think we're, you know, trying to make a point of whether - what words to use here.
He's very happy with the outcome, and I think he should be happy with the outcome.
I would be happy with this outcome if I were in his shoes.
So, yes, I think, you know, getting in the semantics of, well, is this - you know, has he been exonerated?
Look, he's not going to be prosecuted for obstruction of justice.
That's - you know, that's the most important thing.
And, finally...
As far as he's concerned, I'm sure...
And, finally, before we let you go, how - what's your view of how Attorney General Barr has handled this so far?
I think that I admire him.
I admire the fact that he got it out so quickly.
Obviously, this is a matter of great importance, and he was able to act quickly.
I think he was probably helped by a very, very complete report.
I think it was - the reason he was able to move so quickly is because of him having total confidence in Bob Mueller and the work of his team.
And I think, you know, Mueller made it easy for him to reach this conclusion and to move forward.
That's the former attorney general of the United States, Alberto Gonzales.
He served under President George W.
Bush.
He's now dean of the law school at Belmont University.
Dean Gonzales, former attorney general, thank you so much for speaking with us once again.
Thank you, Michel.
This is Day to Day.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
The story today is Pennsylvania.
But on an election reporting trip there earlier this month, I found something that left the politics tasting a little bland.
Portfolio.com, which caters to people who have portfolios, says a local eatery in a small Pennsylvania town, Kennett Square, is the most difficult reservation-get in the country.
Welcome to Talula's Table.
It doesn't look tremendously promising right now.

I think the writers are hoping that if they let Dave Letterman go out there with his writers, and Jay Leno is at a tremendous disadvantage and it's incredibly obvious, that NBC will then start to get panicky.
He'll - Leno will pressure them to make a deal, and then NBC will make a deal, at which point the other networks will want to make a deal.
But I think at this point the networks would rather undergo extreme torture before they would give the Writers Guild any kind of deal.
So there's no way that they'll look towards Letterman and say, okay, this is a model we could follow?
They may look, but they will not say this is a model we can follow because they had an opportunity to make this deal in December and the walked away from the table then.
So it's hard to understand why they would then reverse themselves.
I think they're - I honestly think, you know, in all of these things there's always an element of emotion.
I think the networks are really mad at the writers, and at this point they don't want to give the writers a deal, period.
So, as for TV in the spring, what do we expect to see if we don't see any resolution at all with this writers strike?

Well, the fear, I think, in the community that depends on television is that this is not only just destroying the current television season, but that this is a time normally when it's pilot season, they're looking at what comes up for next season, and that this could - if it drags on, as it appears to be doing now, obliterate next year's season.

Now, I have to feel on some level that the network, you know, they can say their model is broken, it's not working for us, but it's still got a lot of - billions of dollars in it, and to torpedo the upcoming season as well as this year's season seems to me to be something they might want to think about.
But who knows, this is a really rancorous situation now.
Okay, Kim.
And looming on the horizon, there are other potential strikes, right, involving the Directors Guild and also the Screen Actors Guild.
Well, I think everybody thinks the Directors Guild will make a deal.
They are going to start negotiating this month.
Everybody's judgment is that they will.
They're going quite early.
People believe they will make a deal.
If that deal is unacceptable to the writers, they'll plan to stay out on strike and hold out until the end of June when the Screen Actors are up.
And the Screen Actors are perceived right now to be pretty militant.
So if that happens and there's no deal and the Screen Actors are unhappy, you're talking about a strike that could really drag on for months.
And it's hard to imagine how that would really be allowed to happen, but at this point it's hard to see how it doesn't happen.
And what about for you and me, people who actually go home and watch TV?
Well, I hope you like reality.
I hope you're up for ""American Gladiators"" and versions of things...
Ah no, not really.
(Soundbite of laughter)
...that were Discovery before but now are on NBC.
I mean the dangerous jobs.
There's going to be a lot of variation on the dangerous job reality shows and stuff like that.
But you will see some fresh programming.
You know, NBC, for example, still has the original mother ship, as they call it, of ""Law and Order"" that they haven't aired and held back.
They haven't aired ""Medium."" There will be some original programming to look at.
It just will be not as much as normally you'd expect.
NPR's Kim Masters, thanks for joining us.
Thank you.
And the ratings are in for last night's talk shows.
They're up big.
Jay Leno topped them all, scoring a 5.3 rating; that's up 47 percent from before the strike.
Letterman up 39 percent.
You're listening to DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
Joining us today from member station WCLK in Atlanta, Georgia, economist and author Julianne Malveaux.
She's the president and CEO of Last Word Productions.
And from the studios of Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois, Mary Frances Berry, professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania.

Finally, Nat Irvin, president of Future Focus 2020 and professor at the Babcock Graduate School of Management in Wake Forest University joins us from member station WFDD in Winston Salem, North Carolina.
So let's start out with Ed Bradley.
Thank you all for joining us.
And yeah, it's - I have to say he really was one of my personal heroes.
And I guess, Nat, I'll start with you.
I mean what do you recollect about him?
Well, first of all, Farai, I think that he was an extraordinarily versatile human being.
A man who was gifted with the ability to be able to look into other folk's souls and then share that with a larger audience.
I think one of the things that just - that America and the world should recognize is just - how difficult it is, how rare it is to be able to produce a person of the quality of Ed Bradley.
You know, a graduate of a Historically Black College and University, who had parents who told him that he could be anything.
And then he did.
He rose to the heights of his profession, earned the respect and admiration, not only of his peers, but of all people who watched him as he shared his insights with us through 60 Minutes.
that with Ed there came a certain authenticity.
An authenticity is just something that you cannot fake.
It's something that people actually come to a certain point and assign to you.
We will say to you after a certain point when you do an interview, we will feel as if that the - you have done that person justice.

Whether we agree with what that person is doing, or has said, or how they have conducted their lives - Ed was able to convey to the audience that - or to a person who would sit with him - that I am going to be fair with you.
What an enormous gift and abilities that Ed Bradley had.
Julianne?
There is no better example of it than what's happened would with BET.
And you look at the content - where is the news content?
I mean, you can watch booty shaking all day long.
And you get this little one-minute news snippets that are dropped in, but nothing of the quality of a lead story.
That went off the air about three years ago when BET was sold to CBS.
It's kind of small inside, more like a neighborhood market.
It's got shelves of fresh bread, exotic mustards, and brownies and who cares about the diet cheeses.
All selected by the co-owner.
She's Aimee Olexy.
All these fridges are filled with, like, our own sausages, our line of soups, lobster pies, and then prepared food.
It's probably 150 cheeses.
This is my domain.
All day, I pretty much just live here.
I've spent my life studying cheese, so I pretty much bore people to tears about that stuff.
(Soundbite of laughter)
So come on back.
Back, yes, back.
That's in the kitchen, where we find Aimee's husband and partner at Talula's, the chef, Bryan Sikora, and he's whisking away at something.
Egg whites, four.
The first course is a egg custard with crab.
We use a little egg white in the sauce.
It's a parsnip sauce.
It's a puree.
We add the egg white sort of at the last minute to aerate it, so it's frothy.
This will be the first of eight courses tonight for 12 lucky patrons who plan ahead.
You see, Talula's Table is just that.
It is one large farm table that seats about a dozen people.
One sitting, one menu, once a night.
Be there at 7:30, if you can get your reservation.
It's really a first come first serve.
At seven o'clock, we answer the phone.
I mean, we go with, like, our computer's time, and that is the first we'll take a reservation for that day one year away.
They are completely booked until then.
So call tomorrow morning, and, if you are the first to get through at precisely 7 a.m., you'll be able to reserve the table for April 23rd, 2009.
It's not a gimmick, says Aimee.
It's simply the way things have worked out.
For her own peace of mind, she will not book any farther in advance.
